metadata.title: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  Occupational Therapy •Occupational therapy led pulmonary rehabilitation uses appropriate, challenging, and purposeful activity to maximize patients’ activity tolerance, functional capabilities and perceived control over their disease.(4) •Using the expertise of OTs and case studies, management of dyspnea practice guidelines were developed. These guidelines are divided into three major areas, with the following goals: –Controlled breathing at rest -Patient uses pursed-lips  breathing with prominent, spontaneous abdominal muscle movement -Patient demonstrates inward displacement of the abdomen with expiration and outward displacement with inspiration through the use of body positions -Patient demonstrates a slow, deep, fluid breathing pattern -Patient demonstrates little movement of shoulder girdle, upper rib cage, and head with breathing -Patient’s expiration is two to three times longer than inspiration –Controlled breathing with activity exertion – during light and heavy physical energy expenditures (2–5 metabolic equivalent levels) -Patient reports less dyspnea with activity exertion -Patient inhales during body movements against gravity, with pulling movements, and with arm elevation    -Patient exhales during the more strenuous part of an activity, during body movements towards gravity, with pushing movements, and with lowering the arms -Patient relieves dyspnea by moving slowly or stopping to rest -Patient uses leaning forward positions (sitting, standing with arms supported and fixed in shoulder internal rotation and adduction) following activity exertion to relieve dyspnea -Patient avoids moderate to maximum forward bending of the torso –Dyspnea-related  anxiety managementPatient reports confidence with managing dyspnea -Patient reports tolerance and less fear of dyspnea -Patient reports less anxiety with participation in physical and social activities associated with dyspnea -Patient reports increased participation in activities that were being avoided due to dyspnea -Patient reports that rest consistently resolves dyspnea –The Canadian Thoracic Society Clinical Practice Guidelines for the management of dyspnea and dyspnea-related  anxiety in patients with COPD,makes the following recommendations:(25) -Evidence supports the use of oral opioids, neuromuscular electrical stimulation, chest wall vibration, pursed-lip breathing, and walking aids for dyspnea management in patients with advanced COPD -Oxygen is recommended for patients with resting hypoxemia only.There is no evidence to support oxygen use to reduce dyspnea in non-hypoxemic patients -There is insufficient evidence to support use of anxiolytic medications, nebulized opioids, acupuncture, acupressure, distractive auditory stimuli such as music, handheld fans, counseling, or psychotherapy –Researchers in Canada conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis  of the use and efficacy of active mind-body therapies (AMBMT)such as yoga, tai chi, qigong, and focused meditation as an adjunct intervention to pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) for patients with COPD(26) -10 RCTs involving 762 participants were included in the research -Primary outcome measures for review were QoL (SF-36), dyspnea (CRQ Dyspnea Scale) and serious adverse events -Results showedthat the addition of AMBMT to PR resulted in statistically significant improvements in QOL measures; however, there were no significant changes in self-reported  dyspnea or occurrence of adverse events. Researchers concluded that further high-quality  studies are needed –Researchers conducting a scoping review and internet scan of occupational therapy research and practice involving adults with chronic diseases identified 19 articles involving patients with COPD. They identified the following practice areas:(16) -Multidisciplinary PR – Three RCTs identified advice on coping with ADLs, mobility devices, and stress management as the OT role. Other studies addressed home modification, energy conservation techniques, cleaning, dressing, feeding, and self-care  for respiratory treatments -Relaxation – one RCT that examined the effect of guided imagery -Practice descriptions describing the use of energy conservation, adaptive techniques during ADLs, strategies to overcome dyspnea, ADL/IADL training, adaptive equipment, work hardening, and leisure education and counseling -Patient perception of OT intervention–  qualitative studies –In a 2018 RCT researchers explored the clinical impact of a quick, one-session  relaxation training for patients with COPD (17) -38 participants with COPD were recruited and randomly assigned to either the experimental group (EG) or control group (CG). Participants in the EG listened to an 11-minute  relaxing audio track, while the CG watched an 11-minute documentary movie with neutral contents -At baseline and shortly after the intervention, participants were assessed. Assessments includedparticipants’ psychological state (psychometric questionnaires) and pulmonary and physiological function (spirometry, oxygen saturation level, and heart rate) -Researchers found that the participants in the EG showed more positive outcomes on cardiac and respiratory function tests and reported decreased anxiety compared to the control group –Researchers in Sweden investigated the effectiveness of energy-conservation  techniques (ECTs) in patients with COPD (19) -32 patients with COPD were included in the study. Participants were instructed in ECTs to use during 5 standard ADL tasks -Energy expenditure (MET and oxygen saturation) was assessed with a gas exchange system during one of the five standard ADLs before and after the 2-week intervention period    -Results showed significantly lower MET and less desaturation while performing the same activity after the intervention –In a 2014 review of the literature seeking to identify the role of occupational therapy in addressing lifestyle behaviors in chronic cardiac, respiratory (including COPD), and diabetic conditions, investigators concluded that occupational performance coaching based on occupational therapy theory could be effective in enabling persons with COPD to maintain healthy lifestyle behaviors(18) . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures
anatomical location body part affected: Lungs; the effects of airflow obstruction can affect every part of body
description: The American Thoracic Society defines COPD as a disease state characterized by the presence of airflow obstruction due to chronic bronchitis or emphysema. It is usually progressive and can be accompanied by airway hyperreactivity.It may be partially reversible(1) –Chronic bronchitis is defined by excessive secretion of bronchial mucus and is manifested in a daily productive cough for 3 or more months or more in at least 2 consecutive years –Emphysema denotes abnormal permanent enlargement of air spaces distal to the terminal bronchiole, with destruction of their walls and without obvious fibrosis

There is a decline in lung function that is both duration-  and dose-dependent.  Cigarette smoking is considered the most important cause of COPD in North America and Western Europe(1) –An estimated 80% of patients with COPD have had significant exposure to cigarette smoke and the remaining 20% usually have a combination of exposure to noxious stimuli (environmental tobacco smoke, occupational dusts and chemicals, and indoor air pollution from biomass fuel used in cooking and heating in poorly ventilated buildings) -Outdoor air pollution, airway infection, familial factors, allergy, and hereditary factors have also been implicated in chronic bronchitis
COPD is a slowly progressive disease that can lead to severe limitation of functional and physical activity, lessening the quality of life, and can ultimately lead to a premature death(2)

It is estimated that in 50% of patients with COPD the condition is undiagnosed. It is recommended that:(2) –any smoker over age 40 complaining of respiratory symptoms (cough, dyspnea, sputum production or activity limitation) should be tested for COPD –diagnosis is confirmed with spirometry –a post-bronchodilator  ratio of forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV 1) to forced vital capacity (FVC), or FEV 1/FVC, of less than 70% is used as a diagnostic criterion for COPD

COPD is the sixth most prevalent chronic medical condition in the United States, impacting more than 5% of the population. It causes more than 700,000 hospitalizations every year and is the fourth leading cause of death in the United States. The annual cost of COPD in the United States exceeds $42 billion(2)

The GOLD classification can be used to describe the severity of COPD. It is a classification of the severity of airflow limitation based on post-bronchodilator  FEV(20)  –GOLD 1 (Mild): FEV 1> / = 80% predicted –GOLD 2 (Moderate): 50% < / = FEV 1 < 80% predicted –GOLD 3 (Severe): 30% < / = FEV 1< 50% predicted –GOLD 4 (Very Severe): FEV 1< 30% predicted

Separately, or as part of the pulmonary rehabilitation team, the occupational therapist (OT) provides interventions to assist clients in maintaining and increasing their occupational performance and participation while living with COPD(3) –Interventions may include the following: -Energy conservation techniques -Retraining in ADLs -Upper extremity strength and ROM training -Educating patient and family members about risk factors and measures to improve symptoms (e.g., smoking cessation) -Lifestyle modifications -Environmental assessment -Medication management -Recommendations for support groups and resources

ICD-10 codes.J44: other chronic obstructive pulmonary disease including emphysema
ICD-10 codes.J44.0: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute lower respiratory infection
ICD-10 codes.J44.1: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with acute exacerbation, unspecified

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients will usually seek treatment in the fifth or sixth decade of life –Complain of excessive cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath, with symptoms present for 10 years or more –Initially complain of dyspnea on exertion, but dyspnea occurs with mild activity as the condition progresses and eventually, in severe disease, can occur at rest

Patients with COPD can demonstrate an inefficient breathing pattern. For example: –on exertion, breathing tends to be rapid and shallow.Little diaphragmatic movement is noted –they can also demonstrate breathing dyssynchrony, in which the abdomen goes inward with inspiration, or even appear to gulp for air

Two symptom patterns emerge as disease progresses:(1) –“Pink puffer” (emphysema predominant) – they will complain of dyspnea and usually present after age 50. If cough is present, a small amount of clear mucoid sputum can be produced. Patients are thin and appear uncomfortable when at rest, with evidence of using accessory muscles of respiration. Chest auscultation is quiet –“Blue bloater” (bronchitis predominant) – they will complain of a chronic cough that produces a mucopurulent sputum and will have frequent exacerbations. Patient often presents in late 30s or 40s with mild dyspnea, and is frequently overweight, cyanotic, and can have evidence of peripheral edema. Chest is noisy with rhonchi and wheezing is often present
In late stages of COPD, pneumonia, pulmonary hypertension, corpulmonale, and chronic respiratory failure are common
Exercise limitation and deconditioning are commonly seen

Periodic exacerbation of symptoms (increased dyspnea, frequency and severity of cough, and sputum volume; or change in sputum color) is hallmark of COPD and commonly follows an infection or can be caused by environmental factors
Patients with advanced emphysema may have evidence of chest hyperinflation (barrel-shaped  chest), use of accessory muscles for breathing, and muscle wasting  Causes & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: If patient shows increasing signs of dyspnea or cyanosis during examination or treatment, contact the patient’s physician or call 911
If patient has undergone surgery for the treatment of COPD, consult the surgeon’s protocol for postoperative treatment

Pay close attention to the patient’s breathing during examination and treatment. It may be necessary to divide the examination into multiple parts if the patient is symptomatic (productive coughing, displaying dyspnea)

pathogenesis: COPD is felt to be a multicomponent disease caused by noxious agents, such as cigarette smoke(2)

An increased exposure to noxious agents leads to oxidative stress, which is believed to trigger the disease in susceptiblepersons(2)–Airflow limitation caused by airway inflammation, mucociliary dysfunction, and structural changes in parenchyma, smallairways, and pulmonary vasculature–Clinical bronchitis with cough and sputum production is a manifestation of large airway involvement as well as smallairway inflammation–In emphysema, there is destruction of alveolar walls and enlargement of alveolar spaces beyond terminal bronchioles.With advancement of the disease, the airspace enlargement creates large empty spaces called bullae. Loss of lung tissueimpairs gas exchange, increases lung volume and hyperinflation, and limits airflow–Vascular involvement includes thickening of the vessel wall and endothelial dysfunction
risk factors: Cigarette smoking(2)–Most patients at diagnosis report a history of more than 20 pack-years–It is estimated that only 20–30%  of smokers develop COPD.This has been linked to a genetic susceptibility
Exposure to environmental tobacco smoke, occupational hazards, and air pollution(2)
The role of recurrent respiratory infections in the development of COPD is controversial(2)

overall contraindications precautions: According to the guidelines set forth by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), pulmonary rehabilitation is not suitable for patients with “unstable cardiac disease, locomotor or neurological difficulties precluding exercise such as severe arthritis or peripheral vascular disease, and people in a terminal phase of an illness or with significant cognitive or psychiatric impairment”(5)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

If patient has undergone surgery for the treatment of COPD, consult the surgeon’s protocol for postoperative treatment

Pay close attention to the patient’s breathing during examination and treatment. It may be necessary to divide the examination into multiple parts if the patient is symptomatic (productive coughing, displaying dyspnea)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document if patient is a smoker and, if so, how many pack-years  history. Ask about onset of disease (often insidious) and exposure to noxious agents (exposure to own and/or environmental tobacco smoke, occupational hazards, and air pollution)

course of treatment.medical management: WHO states that effective COPD management includes 4 components—assess and monitor disease, reduce risk factors, manage stable COPD, and manage exacerbations—and 7 goals—prevent disease progression, relieve symptoms, improve exercise tolerance, improve health status, prevent and treat complications,(1) Smoking cessation  single most important intervention  Oxygen therapy Inhaled bronchodilators  improve symptoms, exercise tolerance, and overall health status, but not decline in lung function Ipratropium bromide, an anticholinergic, is considered a first-line  agent Beta-2-agonists  (e.g., albuterol, metaproterenol) are effective but have shorter effect duration and may have side effects of tachycardia, tremor, or hypokalemia Corticosteroids  not considered first line of defense as no effect on mortality or decline of lung function with corticosteroid use Theophylline  for treatment of patients who do not achieve adequate symptom control with inhaled bronchodilators and corticosteroids Antibiotics  for acute exacerbation, acute bronchitis, and to prevent acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis. They are felt to be of most benefit to patients with COPD exacerbation associated with increased sputum purulence accompanied by dyspnea or an increase in quantity of sputum Pulmonary rehabilitation  comprehensive program recommended for patients who have severe dyspnea, reduced QOL, or frequent hospitalizations despite medical therapy Other measures  adequate systemic hydration, effective cough training methods, hand-held flutter device and postural drainage in the treatment of chronic bronchitis with secretions Surgery for COPD Lung transplantation  requirements are severe lung disease, limited ADLs, exhaustion of medical therapy, ambulatory status, potential for pulmonary rehabilitation, limited life expectancy without transplantation, adequate function of other organ systems, and good social support system. Twoyear  survival rate is 75% Lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS)  for patients with advanced diffuse emphysema and lung hyperinflation(1) The addition of LVRS to pulmonary rehabilitation significantly improved both generic and disease-specific healthrelated  quality of life (HRQOL) measures up to 36 months after surgery when compared to a pulmonary rehabilitation only group(7) Bullectomy  a palliative procedure for patients with severe bullous emphysema(1)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? See Medical Management  above
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Mid-disease   increased reductions in FEV 1 and in the FEV 1/FVC ratio
Severe disease  FVC is markedly reduced
Increase in residual volume, in total lung capacity and in their ratio indicative of air trapping, particularly in emphysema
Compensated respiratory acidosis occurs in patients with chronic respiratory failure
Positive cultures poorly correlate to exacerbations

ECG(1)  sinus tachycardia may be present and, in advanced disease, chronic pulmonary hypertension may cause ECG changes typical of corpulmonale. Supraventricular arrhythmias and ventricular irritability can occur
Radiographs  not usually effective for diagnosing bronchitis or emphysema unless enlargement of central pulmonary arteries is seen, which is evidence of advanced disease
CT of the chest with high resolution is more sensitive and specific than plain radiographs
6-minute  walk test (6MWT) for distance can be used to assess exercise tolerance and rule out exercise-induced hypoxemia(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they are helpful
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) Note any factors that cause exacerbations of COPD -Aggravating factors include tobacco smoke, occupational dusts and chemicals, and indoor air pollution from biomass fuel used in cooking and heating in poorly ventilated buildings as well as illnesses that cause respiratory symptoms (e.g., flu, bronchitis)(1)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Note if patient requires head of bed to be raised in order to sleep
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, flu-like  symptoms, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note any use of supplemental oxygen at present or in the past. Note the type of oxygen used. Does client use oxygen continually or on an as-needed  basis? Does the patient require a CPAP or BiPAP at night? -Supplemental oxygen is generally recommended only for patients with COPD with resting hypoxemia (1) -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes/No -If Yes, describe

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Note any prior admission or ER visits that were due to COPD exacerbation. Was patient hospitalized? Note any previous treatment and response to treatment. Has the patient been in pulmonary rehabilitation in the past?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders The course of COPD may be complicated by multiple extrapulmonary comorbidities such as cardiac disease, depression, osteoporosis, and muscle wasting(2) Beck Depression InventoryII  may be used to assess depression(13)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: (e.g., does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?) Are there activities to which the patient would like to return but that are currently limited by COPD symptoms?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any functional limitations and ask about any assistance that the patient receives from caregivers. Ask about adaptive equipment used in the home and outside the home
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Specifically ask how oxygen is delivered in the home, if applicable. Note if home has been assessed previously for the need for modifications for safety

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note height and weight. Note whether patient tends to be a “pink puffer” (thin and underweight) or a “blue bloater” (overweight with evidence of edema)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices –Researchers in Europe who compared the effects of adding a new walking aid on the number of steps needed to complete the 6MWT and the metabolic demands of the test in patients with COPD concluded that exercise performance can be improved using walking aids(8) -21 patients with COPD performed two 6MWTs during prerehabilitation assessments.Two additional 6MWTs were randomly performed on two consecutive days, once with a rollator and once with a walker -Walking pattern was assessed with an accelerometer.Metabolic demands,including oxygen uptake, ventilation, heart rate, and oxygen saturation, were measured with a mobile device. Additional outcome measures used included the Borg perceived rate of exertion (PRE) scale -Researchers found that use of a walker led to significant improvement in the 6MWT compared to the rollator, with the same metabolic demands, comparable Borg scores, and greater satisfaction (19% of participants reported feeling ashamed using the rollator compared to 10% using a standard walker)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADL tasks involving weight shifting –Tinetti Balance Scale –Berg Balance Scale –Functional reach test
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: The modified shuttle walk test (MSWT) is a standardized externally paced submaximal endurance walking test that has been shown to have high concurrent validity and test-retest reliability for patients with COPD(9)
Special attention should be taken to measure respiratory rate and blood oxygen saturation during examination and treatment(3)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulses bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesBed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activitya measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility –FIM – an 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –Note use of braces or ambulatory aids for walking –If the patient presents with impaired gait or decreased safety while ambulating, referral to physical therapy may be appropriateAssess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities; describe the quality of movement –Observe manual dexterity; serial opposition or rapidly touching each finger to thumb in succession –Motor Assessment Scale -Assesses motor function; includes disability and impairment measures; assessments include arm and hand movements, tone, and mobility
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT with muscles with contracture or in the presence of abnormal tone or coordination –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally –Assess grip force in functional tasks (e.g., holding coffee cup, shaking hand) –Assess pinch strength
relevant tests and measures.posture: Poor posture may impact the ability of a patient to complete occupational tasks such as feeding, dressing, oral care, transfers, and meal preparation. Difficulty with breathing may lead to postural changes, especially in the thoracic area –Document static/dynamic posture in both sitting/standing throughout a variety of tasks –Note posture with/without adaptive equipment  –In an exploratory study designed to explore interactions between pulmonary function, posture, and upper quadrant mobility, researchers found an association between impaired pulmonary function and postural and mobility adaptations(21) -Based on a study comparing 15 COPD patients with 15 age-matched  healthy controls conducted in Portugal -COPD patients were more likely to have a forward head posture, decreased head mobility, and less shoulder flexion
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active range of motion (AROM) and passive range of motion (PROM) of both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers –Note pain response with any active movement or stretchingAssess safety and ability to perform ADLs combing hair, upper and lower body dressing, managing clothing, using the toilet, applying makeup or shaving the face, bathing, and eating –FIM testing, the Physical Self-Maintenance  Scale (PSMS), the Cognitive Performance Test (CPT), the Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS), and the Barthel Index of Activities of Daily Living are appropriate standardized measures for ADLs –If possible, obtain caregiver’s perspective on the patient’s ability to complete ADLs. Identification of both the patient’s and caregiver’s perspective on ADL ability can facilitate communication and increase shared responsibility(23) -Researchers comparing patient versus “proxy” perception of ADL ability found differences between groups in both the perception of ability to complete ADLs and which ADLs were most considered problematic -Based on a group of 194 patients with moderate to very severe COPD and their caregivers living in the Netherlands -ADLs were assessed using the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation –Examine for sensory impairment bilaterally; pin-prick, temperature, pressure, proprioception, and vibration
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Chronic Respiratory Disease Questionnaire Self-Administered Standardized (CRQ-SAS)(19) –COPD Assessment Test (CAT) – assesses symptoms(20) –Occupational Performance History Interview II (OPH-II) –Occupational Self-Assessment  (OSA) –Performance Assessment of Self-Care  Skills (PASS) –Short Form-36  (SF-36) –Activity Card Sort (ACS) –Sickness Impact Profile (for generic HRQOL) and V AS scale for disease-specific  (QOL) –Researchers in China developed a 26-item  tool that assesses patients with COPD to identify relevant ADLs called the Activities of Daily Living Inventory (ADLI). Testing demonstrated it to be a valid, comprehensive ADL tool for assessing patients with COPD(10)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Note patient’s ability to communicate and level of arousal as well as memory, attention, problem solving, and orientation to person, place, time, and situation  –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is appropriate

patient able to manage copd disease and: Respiratory rate and observation of breathing pattern
Patient report of–less dyspnea–more activity–resumption of physical and social activities unable to pursue before–use of support groups/resources
Sickness Impact Profile (for generic HRQOL) and V AS scale for disease-specific  QOL(7)

maintenance or prevention: COPD is largely preventable through elimination of long-term  exposure to tobacco smoke or other inhaled toxins(1,2)
Smoking cessation(1) significantly alters disease in patients with early evidence of airflow obstruction slows the decline of FEV1 in middle-aged  smokers with mild airway obstruction
Vaccination against seasonal and epidemic influenza A and pneumococcal infection may be of benefit(1)
